projects.title: KidsRightsIndex
projects.description: The KidsRights Index seeks to find ways to integrate and make more broadly accessible existing data on the state of children’s rights in the world. It is based on quantitative data from UNICEF’s State of the World’s Children and qualitative data from the ‘Concluding Observations’ of the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child. The project is conducted together with Erasmus School of Economics (Prof. Philip Hans Franses and, until 2023, Prof. Dinand Webbink), and with the Dutch NGO KidsRights. The first KidsRights Index was launched in November 2013, in the Peace Palace in The Hague. In January 2014 the KRI project was presented to the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child. In June 2014 an international experts meeting was organized at the International Institute of Social Studies to discuss the results so far, and the challenges ahead, with designers of other indexes (on Africa and South Asia), a member (Ms. Maria Herczogh) and a former Chair (Prof. Jaap Doek) of the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child, a representative of UNICEF New York and various other practitioners in this field. Since then, the KidsRights Index has been receiving ever more media coverage and has given rise to exchanges on children's rights with various groups of professional, and with governments and NGOs.  In October 2022 we launched the tenth edition.

projects.title: EUR Honorary Doctorate Navi Pillay
projects.description: On 9 June 2016 I had the distinct honor to serve as one of the honorary promotors for Mrs. Navi Pillay. Pillay received a honorary doctorate from Erasmus University Rotterdam to underline the importance of her work for justice, equality and human rights in South Africa and in the world. Pillay has worked as a human rights lawyer, national and international judge and served as UN High Commissioner for Human Rights between 2008 and 2014. In my part of the laudatio (formal public words of praise) I highlighted Pillay's contributions to the fight for the right to development and on LGBTI issues. In addition, I explained how she has incorporated human rights into her personal style of leadership.

projects.title: Teaching human rights at Mekelle University, Ethiopia
projects.description: In 2014 and 2015 I visited Mekelle University 3 times to co-teach courses on international human rights law, and on globalization and international human rights law, in the first locally administered LLM programme in international law, This takes place as part of a capacity building project of the University of Amsterdam, co-sponsored by the Dutch Embassy in Ethiopia, both universities involved and Ethiopia's Ministry of Justice. This is also a good opportunity to meet up with some of the ISS alumni in Mekelle!

projects.title: Contribution to UN OHCHR meeting on the Right to Development
projects.description: On 2 December 2014, together with my colleague Jumoke Oduwole from Nigeria (Prince Claus Chair Holder 2013-2015), I participated in an event on the right to development organized by the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights. This event, 'Sustainable Development with Dignity and Justice for All - Realizing the Right to Development for Present and Future Generations', commemorated the 28th anniversary of the United Nations Declaration on the Right to Development. It was well attended, with representatives from the UN member states Brazil, China, Egypt, Greece, India, Ireland, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Quatar and from the Holy See, and a large number of youth participants in the Change Makers Summit that took place simultaneously.  My talk on 'Advancing the Right to Development: A Child Rights-Based Approach' is available through http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Issues/Development/Anniversary2014/KarinArts.docx

projects.title: Hague Talks
projects.description: On 19 September I participated in the HagueTalks. It was a very inspiring event, held in the Peace Palace, and meant to be "a meeting place for creative minds, peace inventors and game changers in the field of peace and justice". The theme was 'Young Justice: Kids in Conflict'. The speakers focused on a very diverse range of aspects, from the role of music and dance, religion, philosophy, art, law (including human rights and children's rights), data and identity. See  http://www.haguetalks.com/ for further general details and the link provided above for my talk on the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and on the KidsrightsIndex
